learning_objectives.objective: Define key terms associated with Annex A 5.7, including Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI), Indicators of Compromise (IoCs), Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs), and types of threat intelligence (strategic, tactical, operational).

Explain the purpose of Annex A 5.7 in ISO 27001:2022, including how it mandates organizations to collect, analyze, and produce threat intelligence to understand and mitigate information security threats.
Apply Annex A 5.7 requirements by mapping sample IoCs or TTPs from a threat feed to an organization's assets and proposing initial mitigation steps.

Analyze the threat intelligence lifecycle (Planning & Direction, Collection, Processing & Exploitation, Analysis & Production, Dissemination, Feedback) and compare it to MITRE ATT&CK framework for identifying adversary behaviors.
Evaluate the effectiveness of a given threat intelligence program against Annex A 5.7 criteria, identifying gaps such as over-reliance on automated feeds versus human analysis.
Design a threat intelligence collection plan tailored to an organization's scope, incorporating diverse sources, ISO 27002 implementation steps, and integration with MITRE ATT&CK.

active_learning.discussion_prompt: How would you apply this concept in your work environment?
active_learning.peer_teaching: In pairs, one learner explains the six stages of the threat intelligence lifecycle (Planning & Direction, Collection, Processing & Exploitation, Analysis & Production, Dissemination, Feedback); the partner teaches it back using a hand-drawn diagram, incorporating Annex A 5.7 requirements.
active_learning.problem_solving: Analyze the Log4Shell (CVE-2021-44228) vulnerability case study: Identify IoCs (e.g., JNDI strings) and TTPs (e.g., exploit development), map them to MITRE ATT&CK (TA0001 Initial Access), apply Annex A 5.7 by proposing collection processes and mitigations, then share solutions in a group debrief.
